wiki_catalogs.name: System Overview
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for the System Overview section focused on the Realtime Chat App. Explain its purpose as a full-stack application enabling anonymous, real-time communication between random users worldwide. Describe the core features including text chat, audio/video calling via WebRTC, file sharing, and random user matching. Document the high-level architecture with frontend (Next.js/React/TypeScript) and backend (Node.js/Express/Socket.IO) components. Illustrate the relationship between key services: guest authentication, session management, real-time messaging, WebRTC signaling, and presence tracking. Include deployment context, scalability considerations, and technology stack synergy. Provide a conceptual diagram showing user flow from entry to chat/call, highlighting critical integration points between frontend and backend. Address security model, anonymity guarantees, and cross-device compatibility.

wiki_catalogs.name: Authentication API
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive API documentation for the Authentication API endpoints in auth.js. Detail the POST /api/guest endpoint for creating guest sessions with optional username, location, gender, and language parameters, and the response containing JWT token and guest user data. Document the GET /api/guest/username endpoint that generates a random username. Include the GET /api/auth/me endpoint for retrieving current guest session information with authentication via JWT in Authorization header. Explain the token-based authentication flow, session persistence using sessionStorage, and token refresh mechanism. Provide curl examples and frontend usage examples using guestAPI from lib/api.ts. Document error responses for validation failures (400) and unauthorized access (401). Address CORS preflight requirements and rate limiting of 5 requests per 15 minutes per IP as defined in middleware/security.js.

wiki_catalogs.name: Component Architecture
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create detailed documentation for the frontend component architecture of the Realtime Chat App. Explain the design and implementation of reusable UI components using React and TypeScript, with a focus on the component library in web/components/ui/ that follows Headless UI principles via Radix UI. Document key components such as VideoCallModal for managing WebRTC call interfaces, MatchingInterface for user matching flow, and GuestUsernameModal for session initialization. Describe component composition patterns, props interfaces, and event handling mechanisms. Include usage examples from actual pages like chat and match. Address accessibility (ARIA labels, keyboard navigation), responsive behavior, and integration with Tailwind CSS for styling. Highlight how components interact with context providers and hooks for state management.

wiki_catalogs.name: Server Initialization
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the Backend Server Initialization process in the Realtime Chat App. Explain the role of server.js as the main entry point that creates the Express application, configures middleware (security, CORS, logging, compression), and sets up HTTP server with Socket.IO integration. Detail the createApp() function that initializes security headers, body parsing, and static file serving. Describe the startServer() function that orchestrates server startup, Redis initialization, route registration, and cleanup tasks. Document the cluster.js module that enables multi-core utilization through Node.js cluster module, including worker creation, error handling, and graceful shutdown propagation. Explain environment-specific behaviors such as debug CORS in production and logging configuration. Include the health check endpoint (/health) and socket stats endpoint (/api/socket/stats) functionality. Provide sequence diagrams showing the server startup flow and cluster initialization process.

wiki_catalogs.name: Guest Session Management
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Guest Session Management sub-feature focused on the Realtime Chat App. Thoroughly explain the implementation of session creation, storage, and retrieval using the RedisGuestManager class. Document how guest sessions are created with unique IDs and usernames via createGuestSession(), stored in Redis with a 2-hour TTL, and fall back to in-memory Map storage if Redis is unavailable. Describe the session data structure including id, sessionId, username, presence status, and connection metadata. Explain the getAllOnlineGuests() and getGuestStats() methods for presence tracking and analytics. Include code examples showing session flow from frontend POST request to backend storage. Address common issues like session expiration, cleanup mechanisms, and fallback behavior during Redis outages. Provide performance considerations for scaling with Redis versus in-memory limitations.

wiki_catalogs.name: Connection Lifecycle Events
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create API documentation for the Socket.IO connection lifecycle events in the Realtime Chat App. Document the connection:established event (serverâ†’client) that includes user metadata (userId, username, socketId, sessionId) upon successful authentication with JWT token. Document the disconnect event handling with automatic presence updates and room cleanup. Explain the reconnection strategy with exponential backoff (reconnectionAttempts: 10, reconnectionDelay: 1000-5000ms) and forceNew: true to prevent connection sharing. Detail the connection error handling for authentication failures and token expiration, including the automatic token regeneration flow in SocketService. Include examples of connection status monitoring using onConnectionChange() and proper disconnection handling with cleanup of event listeners. Provide sequence diagrams showing the full connection handshake process and reconnection scenarios.

wiki_catalogs.name: Text Chat System
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Text Chat System implementation. Thoroughly explain the message lifecycle from user input to delivery confirmation, including text message validation, real-time transmission via Socket.IO, and message status tracking (sent/delivered). Document the implementation of typing indicators with start/stop events and their visual representation in the UI. Detail the message history management and display logic in the chat interface. Explain the integration between frontend components (MessageList, ChatInput) and the socket service for message handling. Include concrete examples from the codebase showing how messages are structured with id, senderId, senderUsername, type, content, and timestamp. Address common issues such as message loss during network interruptions and their solutions through client acknowledgments. Provide performance considerations for handling high message volumes and strategies for message queuing.

wiki_catalogs.name: WebRTC Call Lifecycle Management
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the WebRTC Call Lifecycle Management section. Thoroughly explain the complete lifecycle of a WebRTC call in the Realtime Chat App, from initiation to termination. Document the state transitions in the useWebRTC hook including 'idle', 'calling', 'ringing', 'connecting', 'connected', and error states. Describe how the startCall, acceptCall, rejectCall, and endCall functions manage state changes and coordinate with Socket.IO signaling. Include the implementation of call timeout logic with CALL_TIMEOUT_DURATION and automatic cleanup on state transitions. Explain how media streams are acquired, attached to video elements, and cleaned up during lifecycle events. Provide concrete examples from useWebRTC.ts showing state management patterns using React useState and useRef to avoid stale closures. Address common issues such as concurrent calls, race conditions, and proper cleanup of peer connections and media tracks. Include debugging tips for lifecycle-related issues using console logs and browser developer tools.

wiki_catalogs.name: Guest User Model
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive data model documentation for the GuestUser entity in the Realtime Chat App. Detail all fields including id (string, unique identifier), sessionId (string, JWT session reference), username (string, display name), isOnline (boolean, connection status), isSearching (boolean, matching state), inChat (boolean, active conversation), connectedUser (string|null, matched peer ID), location (object with country/city), gender (string|null), language (string|null), socketId (string|null, current WebSocket identifier), lastSeen (ISO string, timestamp), createdAt (ISO string), and connectedAt (ISO string|null). Document the Redis storage strategy using hash structures (guest:{sessionId}) with 2-hour TTL for session expiration. Explain how the in-memory fallback works when Redis is unavailable. Describe data access patterns for user lookup by sessionId and connectedUser queries. Include sample Redis commands used for CRUD operations and performance considerations for high-concurrency user presence tracking. Address data validation rules in guestController.js and synchronization between frontend GuestSessionContext and backend state.

wiki_catalogs.name: Connection Problems
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for connection problems in the Realtime Chat App. Explain common connection issues such as socket connection timeouts, failed handshakes, and network interruptions. Document the implementation of the socket connection retry mechanism in web/lib/socket.ts, including error handling for 'connect_error' events and automatic reconnection logic. Detail how the backend socket server handles connection authentication and session validation. Include examples of debugging connection issues using browser developer tools and server logs. Address solutions for CORS-related connection problems from cors-debug.js middleware. Provide troubleshooting steps for users behind restrictive firewalls or proxies. Explain the role of the socket service in maintaining persistent connections and handling network state changes.

wiki_catalogs.name: Server Middleware Configuration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Server Middleware Configuration in the Realtime Chat App. Thoroughly explain the implementation of the createApp() function that initializes essential Express middleware. Document the purpose and configuration of each middleware: helmet for security headers, CORS handling (debugCors in production, cors otherwise), body parsing with size limits, input sanitization, request logging (excluding test environment), and compression for performance. Detail the static file serving setup for uploaded files under /uploads. Explain the integration of custom middleware like extractClientIP and securityHeaders. Include code examples from server.js showing middleware ordering and conditional logic based on NODE_ENV. Address common configuration issues such as CORS conflicts, payload size limits, and security header overrides. Provide best practices for middleware optimization and performance impact.

wiki_catalogs.name: UI Component Library
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create detailed documentation for the UI component library in web/components/ui/ that implements Headless UI principles using Radix UI. Explain how these components provide accessible, unstyled primitives enhanced with Tailwind CSS for styling. Document the implementation of key components like Button, Card, Dialog, Avatar, and Badge, including their props, variants, and usage patterns. Include examples of how these components are used in higher-level application components. Address accessibility features such as keyboard navigation, ARIA attributes, and screen reader support. Highlight the design system approach with consistent spacing, typography, and color scales.

wiki_catalogs.name: Authentication Middleware
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Authentication Middleware (auth.js) in the Realtime Chat App backend. Thoroughly explain its role in JWT token validation, guest session extraction, and user authentication for both REST APIs and Socket.IO connections. Document the middleware's implementation of token verification using the jwt.verify method, error handling for expired or invalid tokens, and attachment of user data to the request object. Include practical examples from the codebase showing how it's applied to routes like /api/auth/me and Socket.IO connection events. Explain the integration with Redis for session validation and the guest authentication flow. Address common issues such as token expiration (401 errors), malformed tokens, and session invalidation, providing debugging approaches and solutions. Include performance considerations for JWT verification overhead and caching strategies.

wiki_catalogs.name: Button Component
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create detailed documentation for the Button component in web/components/ui/button.tsx. Explain its implementation using Radix UI primitives and styling with Tailwind CSS. Document all props including variant (primary, secondary, destructive, outline, ghost, link), size (default, sm, lg, icon), and loading state. Include usage examples from the application such as in VideoCallModal and MatchingInterface. Describe accessibility features like proper focus states and ARIA labels. Highlight how the component integrates with React states and handles loading states during async operations like call initiation or matching. Address customization options and theming consistency across the application.

wiki_catalogs.name: Guest Session Management
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive API documentation for the Guest Session Management routes in the Realtime Chat App. Detail the RESTful endpoints for creating guest sessions, retrieving session data, and managing guest metadata. Document the POST /api/guest endpoint for session creation with request body schema including username and optional preferences, and response containing JWT token. Explain the GET /api/guest/me endpoint that returns authenticated guest information using JWT validation via authenticateToken middleware. Describe the GET /api/guest/username endpoint that generates random usernames without authentication. Document the GET /api/guest/:sessionId endpoint for public session lookup. Include the POST /api/guest/location endpoint for updating guest location, gender, and language preferences with proper authentication. For each endpoint, specify HTTP method, URL pattern, request/response formats, status codes, and error cases. Illustrate the controller delegation pattern where routes invoke guestController functions. Provide curl examples for each endpoint and explain the validation flow through validateGuestUsername middleware. Address security considerations around JWT token issuance and session privacy.

wiki_catalogs.name: Technology Stack
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for the Technology Stack section focused on the Realtime Chat App. Detail the full technology stack used across frontend and backend. For the frontend: Next.js 14 with App Router, React 18, TypeScript, Tailwind CSS, Radix UI components, and Socket.IO client. For the backend: Node.js 18+, Express.js, Socket.IO server, Redis for session management, MongoDB for persistent storage, JWT for authentication, and Winston for logging. Explain the role of each technology in the system, version compatibility, and rationale for selection. Document testing stack: Jest for unit and integration tests, React Testing Library. Include build and deployment tools: PM2 for process management, Vercel for frontend, and ecosystem.config.js for backend orchestration. Provide guidance on dependency management using pnpm as indicated by pnpm-lock.yaml.

wiki_catalogs.name: User Management API
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed documentation for the User Management API endpoints in users.js. Cover the GET /api/users/online endpoint that returns all currently online users, and GET /api/users/available for users available for matching, both requiring JWT authentication. Document the POST /api/users/device endpoint for registering or updating device information with deviceId in request body, including validation via validateDeviceUpdate middleware. Include the GET /api/users/stats endpoint for retrieving system statistics like total, online, available, and connected users. Explain the integration with Redis for real-time user presence tracking and the role of authenticateToken middleware. Provide code examples using userAPI from lib/api.ts, including error handling for 401 (unauthorized) and 429 (rate limited) responses. Describe use cases such as updating device context on login and fetching available users before initiating a match.

wiki_catalogs.name: State Management
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop comprehensive documentation for the state management system in the Realtime Chat App frontend. Detail the use of React Context API through ChatContext and GuestSessionContext to manage global application state including user session data, connection status, and active chat partners. Explain how custom hooks like useWebRTC and useCallLogs encapsulate feature-specific logic and provide clean interfaces to components. Document state initialization, update patterns, and side effect handling. Illustrate data flow from context providers to consuming components with real code examples. Address performance considerations such as memoization, re-render optimization, and context splitting strategies. Include guidance on testing context providers and mocking state in unit tests.

wiki_catalogs.name: Middleware Architecture
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Middleware Architecture of the Realtime Chat App backend. Thoroughly explain each middleware component: auth.js for JWT token validation and guest session extraction; security.js for implementing helmet, rate limiting (authLimiter, apiLimiter), input sanitization, and security headers; cors-debug.js for handling cross-origin requests with environment-specific configurations; upload.js for managing temporary file cleanup; and validation.js for request data validation. Document the middleware execution order in the request lifecycle, including error handling with errorHandler. Explain the rate limiting strategies for different endpoints and the security rationale behind each middleware. Include practical examples from the codebase showing how middleware is applied to routes and Socket.IO connections. Address common issues like CORS failures and token expiration, with solutions and debugging approaches. Provide performance considerations for middleware overhead and optimization tips.

wiki_catalogs.name: JWT Authentication Flow
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the JWT Authentication Flow sub-feature focused on the Realtime Chat App. Thoroughly explain the token generation process in generateToken() using Node.js JWT library with 2-hour expiration. Document how tokens are issued during guest session creation in createGuestSession() with payload containing userId, sessionId, username, and isGuest flag. Describe the authentication middleware's role in validating tokens for both HTTP routes and Socket.IO connections, extracting user data for context. Explain token storage in frontend sessionStorage and transmission via Socket.IO auth token. Include examples of token structure, validation logic, and error handling for expired/invalid tokens. Address security considerations: token secrecy, expiration enforcement, and protection against tampering. Provide troubleshooting guidance for common token-related issues like 'invalid token' errors and session mismatches.

wiki_catalogs.name: User Matching System
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create API documentation for the user matching system in the Realtime Chat App. Document the clientâ†’server user:match event that initiates random user matching and the serverâ†’client user:match:searching event confirming search initiation. Detail the user:matched event (serverâ†’client) that contains matchedUser object with id, username, and profile data, plus roomId for the private chat room. Document the user:match:cancel event for stopping search and corresponding user:match:cancelled confirmation. Explain the matching algorithm that filters available guests by isSearching=true and no connectedUser, selects randomly, and creates a sorted roomId. Include the room joining mechanism where both users join the same roomId and receive room:user_joined notifications. Provide examples of implementing matching UI states (searching, matched, cancelled) using SocketService methods requestMatch() and cancelMatch().

wiki_catalogs.name: File Sharing Mechanism
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the File Sharing Mechanism. Explain the complete workflow from file selection to download, including client-side file validation, upload to temporary storage, and generation of shareable links. Document the implementation of temporary file storage with automatic expiration using the tempFileStorage utility. Detail the message structure for file sharing with type: 'file' and content containing file metadata and download URL. Explain the security considerations for file uploads including size limits, type restrictions, and virus scanning if implemented. Describe the cleanup process for temporary files when a chat room is closed or users disconnect. Include examples from the codebase showing how file messages are handled in both frontend (FilePreview component) and backend (handleChatMessage function). Address common issues such as large file transfers, upload failures, and expired file links with appropriate solutions.

wiki_catalogs.name: WebRTC Signaling Protocol
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive API documentation for the WebRTC Signaling Protocol used in the Realtime Chat App. Document the WebSocket event-based communication between frontend and backend for WebRTC signaling. For each event, specify the event name, payload structure, direction (client-server), and purpose: 'webrtc:offer' (clientâ†’server) with RTCSessionDescriptionInit and call type, 'webrtc:answer' (clientâ†’server) with RTCSessionDescriptionInit, 'webrtc:ice-candidate' (clientâ†’server) with RTCIceCandidate, 'webrtc:call-reject' (clientâ†’server), 'webrtc:call-end' (clientâ†’server), and 'webrtc:call-timeout' (clientâ†’server). Explain how socketService in lib/socket.ts abstracts these events and how socketHandlers.js routes them to connected peers. Document error handling strategies, message validation, and security considerations including authentication checks via JWT. Include sequence diagrams showing the signaling flow during call setup and teardown. Provide client implementation guidelines for handling asynchronous events and maintaining proper call state. Address performance considerations such as message batching and connection reliability.

wiki_catalogs.name: Message Model
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive data model documentation for the Message entity in the Realtime Chat App. Detail fields: id (string, unique message identifier), senderId (string, GuestUser ID), senderUsername (string, sender's display name), type (enum: text/file/voice/system), content (string for text, object with fileId, filename, fileType, fileSize, tempUrl, downloadUrl, isImage, fileTypeCategory, expiresAt, duration for media), timestamp (ISO string), status (enum: sending/sent/delivered), and isSystemMessage (boolean). Document the message lifecycle from creation in socketHandlers.js through validation, delivery confirmation, and persistence. Explain the content structure differences between message types and how file metadata is handled. Describe the real-time delivery flow: sender emits chat:message, recipient receives chat:message, sender gets chat:message:sent, and recipient triggers chat:message:delivered. Include sample message payloads for each type and error handling for invalid formats. Address performance considerations for message broadcasting and storage implications of temporary file URLs.

wiki_catalogs.name: Authentication Failures
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for authentication failures in the Realtime Chat App. Explain common authentication issues such as expired JWT tokens, invalid credentials, and session mismatches. Document the token expiration handling mechanism implemented in web/contexts/GuestSessionContext.tsx, including automatic token regeneration and session cleanup. Detail how the auth middleware validates tokens on API requests and socket connections. Include examples from TEST_TOKEN_EXPIRATION.md showing test scenarios for expired token handling. Explain the flow when a user's token expires and how the system automatically creates a new guest session. Provide troubleshooting steps for users encountering authentication errors, including checking token validity and clearing browser storage. Address the synchronization between socket service authentication and React context state.

wiki_catalogs.name: Server Startup Orchestration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Server Startup Orchestration process in the Realtime Chat App. Thoroughly explain the startServer() function that coordinates the entire server initialization sequence. Document the creation of the Express app, HTTP server, and Socket.IO integration through createSocketServer(). Detail the registration of routes via initializeRoutes() including health check (/health), CORS test (/api/cors-test), and socket statistics (/api/socket/stats) endpoints. Explain the error handling setup with graceful shutdown handlers for SIGTERM, SIGINT, uncaught exceptions, and unhandled rejections. Describe the asynchronous Redis initialization with error fallback behavior. Include the cleanup task scheduling for temporary files. Provide sequence diagrams showing the startup flow and dependency initialization order. Address common startup issues like port conflicts, Redis connection failures, and route registration errors.

wiki_catalogs.name: Video Call Modal
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the VideoCallModal component that manages WebRTC audio/video calls in the Realtime Chat App. Thoroughly explain the implementation details including the use of React hooks for state management, integration with the WebRTC hook for peer connection handling, and the use of framer-motion for animations. Document the component's interface with props like isOpen, connectedUser, localStream, remoteStream, and callState. Explain the domain model of call states (idle, calling, ringing, connecting, connected) and how they drive UI changes. Address common issues like video not displaying when toggled and provide solutions implemented in the code. Make content accessible to beginners while providing sufficient technical depth for experienced developers.

wiki_catalogs.name: Security Middleware
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Security Middleware (security.js) in the Realtime Chat App backend. Thoroughly explain its implementation of helmet for HTTP header security, rate limiting using express-rate-limit (authLimiter for authentication endpoints, apiLimiter for general API routes), input sanitization, and security headers. Document the configuration of rate limits (e.g., 100 requests per 15 minutes for auth endpoints) and the rationale behind each security measure. Include practical examples from the codebase showing how helmet is configured to hide powered-by headers and how rate limiters are applied to specific routes. Address common issues like CORS preflight failures due to security headers, rate limit exhaustion, and potential bypass techniques, with solutions and monitoring approaches. Provide performance considerations for the overhead of security checks and optimization tips for high-traffic scenarios.

wiki_catalogs.name: Card Component
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Card component used throughout the application for displaying user interfaces such as matching status and chat containers. Document its composition pattern with CardHeader, CardTitle, CardDescription, and CardContent. Explain how it uses Tailwind CSS for consistent spacing and shadow effects. Provide examples of its usage in the MatchingInterface and chat page. Address responsive behavior and accessibility considerations. Include guidance on extending the component for custom use cases while maintaining design system consistency.

wiki_catalogs.name: File Upload Management
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed documentation for the File Upload Management system in the backend. Cover the POST /api/files/upload endpoint for general file uploads and POST /api/files/voice for voice note uploads. Explain the middleware chain: uploadLimiter for rate limiting, authenticateToken for JWT validation, uploadSingle for multipart form parsing, and validation middleware (validateFileMetadata, validateVoiceNote) for content inspection. Document request requirements including multipart/form-data encoding and expected fields (file, metadata). Describe the controller functions uploadFile and uploadVoice that process and store files. Include response formats for successful uploads (containing file ID and metadata) and error cases (validation failures, upload limits). Explain the debug endpoint GET /api/files/debug/users for monitoring connected users during development. Provide example requests with curl and FormData. Address performance considerations around file size limits, rate limiting thresholds, and security aspects of file type validation. Document the relationship between upload middleware and controller logic.

wiki_catalogs.name: Directory Structure Breakdown
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for the Directory Structure Breakdown section focused on the Realtime Chat App. Provide a detailed explanation of the project's directory organization, starting with the root-level division into backend/ and web/ directories. Document the backend/src structure: config/ for database and logger setup, controllers/ for business logic (guest, user, file), middleware/ for auth, CORS, security, and validation, routes/ for API and socket endpoints, socket/ for real-time event handling, and utils/ for shared functionality. wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create API documentation for the chat messaging system in the Realtime Chat App. Document the clientâ†’server chat:message event with payload containing type (text/file/voice), content, and timestamp, and the serverâ†’client chat:message event that broadcasts messages to the room. wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Presence and Statistics System. wiki_catalogs.name: WebRTC Session Model
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive data model documentation for the WebRTCSession signaling data in the Realtime Chat App. Document the ephemeral nature of this data stored in memory rather than persistent storage. Detail the signaling message structure: offer (SDP object with type and sdp), answer (SDP object), ICE candidates (array of RTCIceCandidateInit objects), call type (audio/video), and timestamps. Explain the signaling flow through Socket.IO events: webrtc:offer, webrtc:answer, webrtc:ice-candidate, webrtc:call-start, webrtc:call-end, webrtc:call-reject, and webrtc:call-timeout. Describe how session state is maintained through connectedUser references in GuestUser model rather than dedicated session storage. Include sample SDP and ICE candidate payloads, and document the error handling for signaling failures. Address the security considerations of peer-to-peer signaling through the server and performance implications of large SDP payloads. Explain the timeout mechanisms and cleanup procedures when calls end or fail.

wiki_catalogs.name: WebRTC and Camera Issues
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for WebRTC and camera issues in the Realtime Chat App. Explain common problems such as ICE connection failures, camera/microphone access permissions, and media stream issues. Document the WebRTC implementation in web/hooks/useWebRTC.ts, including peer connection setup, ICE candidate handling, and signaling flow. Detail the fixes outlined in WEBRTC_FIX.md for ICE candidate timing race conditions and connection state management. Explain how STUN servers are configured and why TURN servers may be needed for restrictive networks. Include troubleshooting steps for mobile-specific WebRTC issues from MOBILE_WEBRTC_GUIDE.md. Provide solutions for common error messages like 'ICE connection failed' and 'InvalidStateError when adding ICE candidate'. Address audio/video synchronization problems and performance optimization techniques.

wiki_catalogs.name: Cluster Management
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Cluster Management system in the Realtime Chat App. Thoroughly explain the implementation of Node.js clustering using the cluster module to leverage multiple CPU cores. Document the master-worker architecture where the master process forks worker processes based on CLUSTER_WORKERS environment variable or CPU count. Detail the event handling for worker lifecycle (online, exit) with automatic restart on failure. Explain the graceful shutdown propagation from master to workers on SIGTERM/SIGINT signals. Describe the logging strategy that differentiates between master and worker processes. Include configuration options for worker count and process management. Address common clustering issues such as load balancing effectiveness, worker memory leaks, and inter-process communication limitations. Provide performance benchmarks showing throughput improvements with multiple workers.

wiki_catalogs.name: Matching Interface
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the MatchingInterface component that handles user matching functionality in the Realtime Chat App. Thoroughly explain the implementation details including the use of React hooks for state management, integration with ChatContext for matching state, and the use of framer-motion for animations. Document the component's interface with props like onMatchFound, and explain how it manages different matching stages (idle, searching, found, failed). Explain the domain model of user matching including search duration tracking and connection handling. Include concrete examples from the code showing how the requestMatch and cancelMatch functions are used. Address common issues like matching timeout and provide solutions implemented in the code. Make content accessible to beginners while providing sufficient technical depth for experienced developers.

wiki_catalogs.name: CORS Configuration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the CORS Configuration (cors-debug.js) in the Realtime Chat App backend. Thoroughly explain its role in handling cross-origin requests with environment-specific configurations, allowing origins like localhost, Render, and Vercel domains. Document the configuration of allowed methods (GET, POST, PUT, DELETE, OPTIONS, PATCH), credentials support, allowed/exposed headers, and preflight response settings. Include practical examples from the codebase showing the whitelist of trusted domains and the regex pattern for Vercel apps. Address common issues like CORS failures during development, credentials not being sent, and preflight request errors, providing debugging approaches and solutions. Explain the security implications of the CORS configuration and best practices for production environments.

wiki_catalogs.name: Overlay Components (Dialog, Drawer, Sheet)
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive documentation for the overlay components: Dialog, Drawer, and Sheet. Explain their shared implementation using Radix UI portals and focus management. Document differences in presentation (modal vs. sliding drawer) and use cases (VideoCallModal uses Dialog, mobile interfaces use Drawer). Detail props like open, onOpenChange, and trigger. Include accessibility features such as focus trapping, ARIA roles, and keyboard navigation (Escape to close). Provide examples of their usage in GuestUsernameModal and VideoCallModal. Address performance considerations with conditional rendering and animation smoothness.

wiki_catalogs.name: Temporary File Serving
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive documentation for the Temporary File Serving system. Detail the three main endpoints: GET /temp/:fileId for inline viewing, GET /download/:fileId for file downloads, and GET /info/:fileId for metadata retrieval. Explain how these routes interface with the tempFileStorage utility to retrieve files from in-memory storage. Document the response headers including Content-Type, Content-Disposition (inline vs attachment), and CORS configuration allowing cross-origin access. Describe the JSON response format for the info endpoint containing file metadata, creation/expires timestamps, and file type categorization. Include the admin endpoint GET /stats for monitoring storage usage. For each route, specify parameters (fileId), success responses, and error cases (400 for missing ID, 404 for expired/missing files, 500 for server errors). Explain the security rationale behind public access to these endpoints (no authentication) due to random fileId generation. Provide example responses and curl commands. Address performance considerations around file expiration, memory usage, and logging via the logger instance.

wiki_catalogs.name: Frontend Architecture
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the Frontend Architecture of the Realtime Chat App. Describe the Next.js 14 App Router implementation with server components and React Server Components. Explain the page structure: home page (page.tsx) for guest session initiation, match/page.tsx for user matching interface, and chat/page.tsx for communication interface. Document the component-based architecture with reusable UI components in components/ui/ following Headless UI principles with Radix. Detail the state management strategy using React Context API (AuthContext, ChatContext) for global state and custom hooks for feature-specific state. Explain the service layer pattern with lib/api.ts for REST calls and lib/socket.ts for Socket.IO communication. Include data flow from user interaction to backend via services, and real-time updates via socket events. Address responsive design implementation and accessibility considerations.

wiki_catalogs.name: Pages and Routing
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Document the Next.js App Router implementation in the Realtime Chat App frontend. Explain the file-based routing structure using the app directory, with page.tsx as the entry point, match/page.tsx for the matching interface, and chat/page.tsx for the communication interface. Describe the use of React Server Components and server-side rendering where applicable. Detail layout.tsx for shared UI elements and metadata. Explain data loading patterns using async components, client-server component boundaries, and hydration behavior. Include navigation flow between pages, state persistence across routes, and SEO considerations. Provide examples of route handling and parameter usage. Address dynamic routing needs and potential future extensions like user profiles or settings pages.

wiki_catalogs.name: Socket.IO Configuration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the Socket.IO Configuration in the Realtime Chat App backend. Explain the createSocketServer() function that initializes the Socket.IO server with CORS policies, transport options, and connection settings. Detail the setupRedisAdapter() function that enables horizontal scaling by connecting to Redis when available, with proper error handling for fallback to single-instance mode. Document the middleware configuration including JWT authentication and rate limiting for WebSocket connections. Describe the connection lifecycle events and error handling mechanisms. Explain the configuration options like pingTimeout, pingInterval, and transports. Include the broadcast and sendToUser utility functions for targeted message delivery. Provide network diagrams showing the difference between single-instance and Redis-clustered deployments. Address performance considerations for connection overhead and scalability limits. Document common configuration issues like connection timeouts and CORS failures, with debugging strategies and optimization tips.

wiki_catalogs.name: WebRTC Signaling Protocol
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create API documentation for the WebRTC signaling protocol in the Realtime Chat App. Document the clientâ†’server webrtc:offer event with offer (SDP) and type (audio/video) fields, and the serverâ†’client webrtc:offer event that forwards offers to the connected user. Detail the webrtc:answer event flow for answer transmission and webrtc:ice-candidate for ICE candidate exchange. Explain the call management events: webrtc:call-end, webrtc:call-reject, and webrtc:call-timeout, including their payload structure with from and fromUsername. Document the error handling with webrtc:error events. Describe the debugging information logged in handleWebRTCOffer() including socket lookups and connection states. Provide examples of implementing WebRTC signaling using SocketService methods sendOffer(), sendAnswer(), sendIceCandidate(), and event listeners for incoming offers. Include sequence diagrams for the full WebRTC call setup and teardown process.

wiki_catalogs.name: Connection Resilience and Recovery
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for Connection Resilience and Recovery. Explain the implementation of automatic reconnection logic with exponential backoff using Socket.IO's reconnection options (reconnectionAttempts, reconnectionDelay, reconnectionDelayMax). Detail the state recovery mechanism that restores user presence and chat context after reconnection. Document the error handling strategy for different connection failure scenarios including network interruptions, server overload, and authentication errors. Explain the token expiration recovery process that automatically generates a new guest session when a JWT token expires. Include examples from the codebase showing the reconnection configuration in SocketService and the error handling in setupEventListeners. Address common issues such as duplicate connections, state inconsistency after reconnection, and race conditions during rapid connection/disconnection cycles with appropriate solutions.

wiki_catalogs.name: Mobile WebRTC Considerations
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for Mobile WebRTC Considerations focused on the Realtime Chat App's mobile compatibility. Address the specific challenges of WebRTC on mobile devices documented in MOBILE_WEBRTC_GUIDE.md and WEBRTC_FIX.md. Explain how the useWebRTC hook handles mobile autoplay restrictions by attaching streams to video elements with muted=true and using play() calls within user gesture contexts. Document the implementation of permission handling on mobile with proper error messaging when users deny camera/microphone access. Describe the mobile-specific getUserMedia constraints in mediaUtils.ts that optimize for mobile device capabilities. Cover orientation changes and how the video layout adapts using responsive design principles. Include debugging strategies for mobile-specific issues such as camera not activating, audio routing problems, and battery optimization killing background connections. Provide performance optimization tips for mobile networks including bandwidth adaptation and codec selection. List known issues and workarounds from WEBRTC_FIX.md such as handling 'NotAllowedError' and 'NotReadableError' on mobile devices.

wiki_catalogs.name: Messaging Delays and Failures
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for messaging delays and failures in the Realtime Chat App. Explain common issues such as delayed message delivery, lost messages, and typing indicator synchronization problems. Document how messages are transmitted through Socket.IO events from frontend to backend and to the recipient. Detail the message validation and error handling in socketHandlers.js. Explain how connection status is monitored and displayed to users through ConnectionStatusDebug.tsx. Include troubleshooting steps for identifying whether delays are caused by network issues, server processing, or client-side rendering. Address solutions for message ordering and delivery confirmation. Provide guidance on using socket event logging to diagnose messaging problems.

wiki_catalogs.name: Health Check Endpoints
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Health Check Endpoints in the Realtime Chat App. Thoroughly explain the implementation of the /health endpoint that returns server status, uptime, version, and timestamp. Document the /api/socket/stats endpoint that provides real-time Socket.IO statistics with rate limiting. Detail the response schemas, HTTP methods, and authentication requirements (none for health checks). Explain how these endpoints are used for monitoring, load balancer health checks, and deployment verification. Include examples of successful and failure responses. Describe the integration with external monitoring tools and alerting systems. Address security considerations for exposing health information and rate limiting strategies to prevent abuse. wiki_catalogs.name: Guest Username Modal
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the GuestUsernameModal component that handles guest user session initialization in the Realtime Chat App. Thoroughly explain the implementation details including the use of React hooks for state management, integration with GuestSessionContext for username generation, and the use of framer-motion for animations. wiki_catalogs.name: File Upload Handling
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the File Upload Handling middleware (upload.js) in the Realtime Chat App backend. wiki_catalogs.name: User Representation Components (Avatar, Badge)

wiki_overview.content:
<blog>
# Comprehensive Project Analysis: Realtime Chat App

## 1. Project Introduction

The Realtime Chat App is a full-stack application designed for instant, anonymous communication between random users worldwide. The system enables real-time text chat, audio, and video calling without requiring user registration, making it accessible and immediate for users seeking spontaneous connections.

**Core Goals and Objectives:**
- Provide a seamless real-time communication platform with WebRTC and Socket.IO
- Enable random user matching for anonymous conversations
- Support file sharing (up to 10MB) and voice notes (up to 5 minutes)
- Ensure scalability and performance through Redis-based clustering
- Maintain stateless chat system with temporary message persistence

**Target Audience:**
- Users seeking anonymous, spontaneous conversations with strangers
- Developers interested in real-time communication architectures
- Teams studying WebRTC implementation patterns in production applications
- Organizations needing scalable chat infrastructure with minimal user friction

## 2. Technical Architecture

### Component Breakdown

The project follows a monorepo structure with two primary components: a Node.js backend and a Next.js frontend. The architecture is designed for real-time communication with WebRTC signaling, Socket.IO for messaging, and Redis for session management and scaling.

```mermaid
flowchart TD
  A[Client Browser] --> B[Next.js Frontend]
  B --> C[Socket.IO Client]
  C --> D[Node.js Backend]
  D --> E[Socket.IO Server]
  E --> F[Redis]
  D --> G[MongoDB]
  H[WebRTC] <--> C
  H <--> E
```

### Design Patterns

The application implements several key design patterns:

- **Singleton Pattern**: The `redisGuestManager` class ensures only one instance manages guest sessions across the application
- **Middleware Pattern**: Express middleware for authentication, rate limiting, CORS, and security headers
- **Event-Driven Architecture**: Socket.IO events for real-time communication between clients
- **State Management**: Context API in React for managing chat and guest session state
- **Service Pattern**: Dedicated service classes like `SocketService` for encapsulating complex functionality

### System Relationships

The backend and frontend communicate through a well-defined API contract using Socket.IO for real-time events and REST endpoints for initial setup. The backend uses Redis as a distributed data store for guest session management, enabling horizontal scaling across multiple server instances.

```mermaid
graph TD
  Frontend[Next.js Frontend] -->|HTTP/HTTPS| Backend[Node.js Backend]
  Frontend -->|WebSocket| SocketIO[Socket.IO]
  Backend -->|Redis Protocol| Redis[Redis]
  Backend -->|MongoDB Protocol| MongoDB[MongoDB]
  SocketIO --> Backend
  Redis -->|Session Management| Backend
  MongoDB -->|User Data| Backend
```

### Data Flow

The data flow begins with guest session creation, proceeds through user matching, and continues with real-time message exchange. All communication is secured with JWT authentication, and temporary files are managed with expiration policies.

```mermaid
flowchart TD
  A[Guest Session Creation] --> B[JWT Token Generation]
  B --> C[Socket.IO Connection]
  C --> D[User Matching Request]
  D --> E[Random User Selection]
  E --> F[Room Creation]
  F --> G[Real-time Messaging]
  G --> H[WebRTC Signaling]
  H --> I[Media Stream Exchange]
  I --> J[File/Voice Sharing]
  J --> K[Session Cleanup]
```

## 3. Key Implementation

### Main Entry Points
- Backend server: [server.js](backend/src/server.js)
- Frontend application: [page.tsx](web/app/page.tsx)
- Socket.IO server: [socketServer.js](backend/src/socket/socketServer.js)
- Chat interface: [chat/page.tsx](web/app/chat/page.tsx)

### Core Modules
- Guest session management: [redisGuestManager.js](backend/src/utils/redisGuestManager.js)
- Socket event handling: [socketHandlers.js](backend/src/socket/socketHandlers.js)
- WebRTC implementation: [useWebRTC.ts](web/hooks/useWebRTC.ts)
- Authentication: [auth.js](backend/src/middleware/auth.js)

### Configuration Approach
- Environment variables: [.env](backend/.env)
- Next.js configuration: [next.config.mjs](web/next.config.mjs)
- PM2 process management: [ecosystem.config.js](backend/ecosystem.config.js)
- API documentation: [API_DOCUMENTATION.md](backend/API_DOCUMENTATION.md)

### External Dependencies
- Real-time communication: [package.json](backend/package.json)
- Frontend framework: [package.json](web/package.json)
- Testing utilities: [jest.config.js](web/jest.config.js)
- UI components: [components.json](web/components.json)

### Integration Points
- Socket.IO client-server communication: [socket.ts](web/lib/socket.ts)
- API service layer: [api.ts](web/lib/api.ts)
- File upload handling: [upload.js](backend/src/middleware/upload.js)
- Cross-origin resource sharing: [cors-debug.js](backend/src/middleware/cors-debug.js)

```mermaid
graph LR
  A[Frontend] --> B[SocketService]
  A --> C[APIService]
  B --> D[Socket.IO]
  C --> E[REST API]
  D --> F[Backend]
  E --> F
  F --> G[Redis]
  F --> H[MongoDB]
  F --> I[File Storage]
```

## 4. Key Features

### Functionality Overview

The Realtime Chat App provides a comprehensive set of features for anonymous, real-time communication:

- **Random User Matching**: Connects users randomly for spontaneous conversations
- **Real-time Messaging**: Text chat with typing indicators and message status
- **WebRTC Communication**: Audio and video calling with signaling through Socket.IO
- **File Sharing**: Support for images, documents, and voice notes up to 10MB
- **Guest Authentication**: JWT-based authentication without registration
- **Responsive Design**: Mobile-first interface with touch-friendly controls

### Implementation Highlights
- Guest session creation: [guestController.js](backend/src/controllers/guestController.js)
- WebRTC signaling: [socketHandlers.js](backend/src/socket/socketHandlers.js)
- File upload validation: [upload.js](backend/src/middleware/upload.js)
- User interface components: [ui/](web/components/ui/)
- State management: [contexts/](web/contexts/)

### Feature Architecture

The application's feature architecture is centered around real-time communication, with multiple interconnected systems working together to provide a seamless user experience.

```mermaid
stateDiagram-v2
    [*] --> Idle
    Idle --> GuestSession: User visits site
    GuestSession --> UsernameSelection: No session
    UsernameSelection --> SessionCreation: Username entered
    SessionCreation --> Connected: JWT received
    Connected --> Matching: Request match
    Matching --> Chatting: Match found
    Chatting --> Calling: Initiate call
    Calling --> MediaExchange: Call connected
    Chatting --> FileSharing: Send file
    FileSharing --> Chatting: File sent
    Calling --> Chatting: Call ended
    Chatting --> Connected: Clear chat
    Connected --> Idle: Exit chat
    Matching --> Connected: Cancel match
```

The system demonstrates a sophisticated approach to real-time communication, combining WebRTC for media streaming with Socket.IO for signaling and messaging. The use of Redis for session management enables horizontal scaling, while the stateless chat system ensures reliability and performance. The frontend implementation leverages Next.js for server-side rendering and React Context for state management, creating a responsive and intuitive user interface.
</blog>
